Hello, I have a question on Page – Slide 16 on the incremental costs in the Investment Banking division. Do you expect further IT investment costs to come and for the cost associated with exiting businesses?

Thanks, thanks for the question. Yeah, I think in general we don't – on the costs associated with exit, I mean there will be costs going forward, but we think they are probably pretty stable. So, it's not that they're going to – it's not that they are going to rise. But we do still – we still are – we do still have some businesses to work out of. In terms of investment on the IT side, yeah, we are going to – and we view that as one of the important aspects of the overall client offering is to make sure that we have strong IT. We've talked some things like adapting our industry-leading AES platform across our fixed income platforms, et cetera, FX, so we probably will have – we will continue to have investment on the IT side.
The question is, more or less, is now a spike for the – for Q3? Is it quite likely that it will come down in Q4 or is it – that's more the intention of the question?
I think it's, yeah, I guess in general we would probably expect on the IT side to remain at higher levels of cost investment.
Yeah, okay. Okay.
Thanks. Next question.
Your next question comes from Kilian Maier from NZB [Neue Zürcher Bank]. Please go ahead.

Good morning. The question would be on 18 – Slide 18 and how really to interpret it? I'm afraid it's kind of a repetition, but I will try my luck nevertheless. So, the right way to look at this would be to take the 4.7, 9.8 annualized, plug in a growth rate, let's say, 10%, and then also annualize the 5.3, and then take out enough percentage, let's say 50% of revenues? And if I take for example that – that gives me 24 billion of revenues, is that the way to look at it, is that the way you look at it and is that – what's the time horizon for that?

Yeah, I mean, what this was – this was actually just – this was just looking at the nine-month revenues and splitting it into those categories. So as you say, we haven't – we haven't done – we haven't shown here the analysis that you are going through. As you're saying, if you wanted to trying to estimate how you thought revenues might develop, then that would be kind of a numerical way to do, a quantitative way to do what sort of I talked about when I think Huw asked the question in terms of estimating timing and scale of impact on the different areas.

So for instance, you mentioned the 5.3 going down by 50%, that would be more than I would estimate, because I think as I mentioned, I think it's got actually a much longer horizon and probably more stability than most – than maybe some people would think. So but on the other hand, I also don't think that the top two boxes go up by 50% either so and there are different time scales, whereas I mentioned, I think probably the green box grows more slowly, because it actually requires us doing things and building our franchises, whereas the grey box is somewhat more dependent on markets.

So if the prime brokerage environment just simply gets better because hedge funds increase their leverage and become more active, then that'll be something that will feed through very quickly in our results, because we've got the market share and growing market share, so. Yeah, so but I guess as you say, that would be a – that would be a quantitative way to kind of go through what I talked about in terms of our – what we view as the prospects for the different areas.
Okay, thank you.
Good, thank you. Next question?
Your next question comes from Chris Marmer from Aerograph. Please go ahead.

Thank you very much. Just, if we're trying to assess the earnings power of the Group sort of in a post crisis environment, do you think that the third quarter result here is reasonably useful as a run rate? I guess with some seasonal weakness on the Private Banking margins, there is some excess returns perhaps in some of the fixed income revenues, but all, in do you think this is somewhat indicative of what this franchise should be able to deliver sort of on an ongoing basis? Thank you.

Yeah, that's really a good question. Obviously, in all these areas, you have the elements of the market, environment, et cetera that will – that plays a big role. So hard to estimate on that. I think what we've – what we've tried to – when we look at the business, I think in general, we feel like the private banking business, our franchise in Switzerland has kind of maintained very good market share, in fact, grown market share, has seen very good net flows in and yet the underlying activity in the – in that part of the business for the industry has been somewhat subdued. So our view is that probably over time, there should be upside to that part of the business.

We believe on the Asset Management side, there are certainly some industry impact, but also for us, as we mentioned, we do feel like we are making progress on our strategy and our focus in those areas. And again, third quarter net new asset flows were encouraging in that regard. We still have more work to do, but so we feel like that's probably an area that should hopefully do better over time.

And then on the Investment Bank, again, it kind of comes back to the same story we've talked a couple of times, which is how do you weigh the different elements of the business mix and how do you view them as developing over time? I think what we've tried to highlight is that we think there is, I mean, obviously it can go either way. We think there is actually more potential for increases if markets continue to be constructive or get better in some of the areas, like we mentioned prime services, cash equities, emerging markets, leveraged finance, then that will give some potential up swing to the revenues. We hope the actions we take on market share will give us some increased revenues and then obviously, you have offsets to that in other areas where margins may come down or volumes may come down.

So I guess that's, maybe that's a long non-answer to your question about whether we think the third quarter is a decent run rate, but we certainly see – certainly conditions were good in the third quarter. There is no question that conditions were good. Particularly for the third quarter, conditions were good, but a number of parts to the business, we still see potential upside and so hard to say how you balance all that out.
Right, but obviously, I mean, with a big disclaimer for broader market conditions, but you would not discourage people to kind of use this as some sort of indication?

I think our hope and our aspiration is that we continue to grow the business and make more over time. But I also think, I mean our hope is also that people do focus on the quality of the returns, because I mean, again, a 25% return on equity on a 16.5% Tier I ratio and on 30% less risk than what we had a year ago is, I think, a pretty high quality performance that's going to be fairly durable through various market environments. So anyway, so I hope also people do focus on that.
Very helpful. Thank you very much.
Okay. Next question.
Your next question comes from Daniel Zolof from Basel Ziton. Please go ahead.

Yes, good morning. Just one question, I understand you're displaying total operations revenues of CHF 3.6 billion. I'm not sure, but I – that's the first time I've – I'm seeing this figure and you're calculating that back until 2006, when you started to integrate Credit Suisse First Boston. I would like you to explain how you calculate actually that figure and maybe also give me an argument whether you are showing that figure now in the context of the whole regulation discussion which is going on? Just the too big to fail problem in Switzerland is being – is being discussed very hotly and I understand that you are trying to show arguments to sustain your business model? Thank you.

Good, thank you. It's actually – actually on the collaboration revenues, we've actually – maybe we haven't – maybe we haven't made it prominent enough, but we've actually been disclosing those revenues, I think, for the last couple of years and so we've been actually on a quarterly basis, we have disclosed them. So if you wanted to see the kind of historical progression, you could go back and look at that or...
Okay.

We could provide it to you. But so, we have been showing it actually on a regular basis. Your question about how it's calculated is a really good question. It's obviously – it's a somewhat complex question to answer. But what we've tried to do is we tried to be pretty honest about what we view as revenues that we do garner as a result of being an integrated bank. Because there are obviously some things, some revenues that are provided by different parts of the bank to other parts that you could actually do outside without much difference in the structure and so we've tried to be pretty honest about where we see real value from the integrated institution.

And we do, I mean, we still – I mean, we've set a target for actually, I think it's 2012 now of getting that number up to 10 billion and that's something that we still – that's still our aspiration. We see a lot of benefit for our business from having a – from this close collaboration and so our hope is that over time, we'll continue to see that develop and we'll make that target, but obviously it's a pretty aggressive target given where we are today.

I think the too big to fail issue, we are – I think certainly that, as you say, is a debate and we are somewhat engaged in the discussions with the regulators and in general with the public. I think that it's an important discussion. I guess our hope is that people, first of all, recognize what's been done already, which is if you look at the changes that have been made in the Credit Suisse business model, substantial reduction in nominal balance sheet, substantial reduction in risk, a much less risky business model, much higher capitalizations than we had a couple of years ago. So in general, that makes the institution much less systemically risky in the first place.

So we hope people actually do recognize what's been done and we're not saying that it's not an important discussion and debate that we should carry on. But there should be recognition of what has changed. And the other thing that we think is important and maybe this is where you were getting out with your collaboration revenue question is, there also has to be some recognition of the positives that come out of the financial system and the large banks, et cetera, particularly here in Switzerland.

We take very seriously our role to provide capital for the economy here, to provide access outside of the country to capital, et cetera and I think that's actually been – I mean, I hope that's been an important part of the growth here and the financial system. So I just think we also need to keep that in context too when we think about kind of the too big to fail issue, but we – we've actually been regularly reporting the collaboration revenue, so.
Thank you.
Thank you very much. Are there any other questions? Okay.
There are no further questions at this time, back to you.

Okay. Well thanks everybody for your questions and thanks for listening to our presentation and for those who are still on listening to the Q&A. I guess, I just wanted to leave you with the couple of points. We – the Investment Bank with this lower risk, more capital efficient, client-focused model, we think we'll continue to produce more sustainable results from its well-diversified portfolio of businesses.

We think also that the – we are happy with the third quality of – the quality of the third quarter performance. We had a very strong return on equity of 25%. We think that complements a strong first half and shows the strategic approach is working well. Secondly, as we mentioned, these returns have been achieved in the context of an industry-leading capital position and with 30% lower risk-weighted assets compared to the third quarter of last year. And third, taken together, we think that the results do demonstrate that the differentiated strategy is providing a good foundation for sustainable, high quality, lower volatility earnings. And lastly, we do believe that we're well positioned for growth in the new competitive landscape.
So with that, I want to thank everybody for your time and your interest and have a good day. Good-bye.
That does conclude today's conference. An e-mail will be sent out shortly advising how to access the replay of this conference. Thank you for joining today's call. You may all disconnect.
